items.description: A stemmed glass with a wide, conical bowl, designed for cocktails served up (chilled, no ice).
Spirit-forward and aromatic cocktails.
The stem prevents warming the drink, while the wide rim enhances aroma.
A shallow, stemmed glass originally designed for champagne, now widely used for cocktails.
Sours, classic shaken or stirred cocktails served without ice.
More stable and practical than a Martini glass, ideal for service.
A smaller, elegant stemmed glass with a narrower opening than a coupe.
Short, spirit-forward cocktails.
Preserves aroma and temperature while offering refined presentation.
A short, wide glass designed for drinks served over ice.
Spirit-forward drinks, short cocktails, neat pours.
Accommodates large ice cubes and allows controlled dilution.
A tall, straight glass used for long drinks with ice and mixers.
Spirit and mixer cocktails.
Maintains carbonation and creates visual balance.
Similar to a highball but taller and narrower.
Citrus-forward long drinks.
Provides extra volume and a cleaner presentation for layered drinks.
A large, curved glass traditionally associated with tropical cocktails.
Tropical and frozen drinks.
Designed for volume, garnish, and visual impact.
A tall, narrow glass that preserves carbonation.
Sparkling cocktails.
Maintains bubbles and elegance.
A stemmed glass with a rounded bowl.
Wine-based cocktails and spritzes.
Enhances aroma and allows gentle swirling.
A decorative ceramic vessel, often themed.
Tiki and tropical cocktails.
Strong visual identity and insulation, not precision.
A small glass designed for quick consumption of spirits.
Shots and measured pours.
Provides volume reference and speed.
Glass choice affects temperature, aroma, dilution, and perception.
Consistency in glassware elevates presentation.
Fewer, well-chosen glass types outperform oversized collections.
Wrong glass equals wrong experience, even with a perfect recipe.
